Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Novel Photonic Enhanced Inorganic-Organic Multi-junction Solar cell

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to combine thin film inorganic and organic solar cells for higher conversion efficiencies (>15%) and better stability. The approach is to utilize a multiple gap arrangement of inorganic and organic thin film cells, coupled with a novel photonic-plasmon structure.

Intellectual Merit:
1. A multiple-gap cell arrangement to harvest the solar spectrum.
2. An inorganic layer as the first, high-gap cell, to remove the damaging ultraviolet and blue photons.
3. The use of a novel periodic photonic-plasmon structure, designed using rigorous scattering-matrix simulation, to optimize photon absorption.
4. The use of organic materials with long wavelength absorption
5. The use of stable contact and hole and electron-transport materials
6. Unique measurement apparatus and analysis for degradation under varying intensities, light spectra and controlled atmosphere.
7. Utilizing easily scalable, roll-to-roll (R2R) nano-imprinting techniques for photonic-plasmonic structures.

Broader Impact:
The technology can be easily transferred to manufacturing using R2R techniques. The solar panels can be molded into the structures of buildings or onto windows. The project will educate graduate and undergraduate students, mentor a post-doctoral scientist, and recruit minority and women students. The research will be incorporated into a new PV course at Iowa State. The solar cells, and a demonstration movie, will be exhibited at the Des Moines Science Center. Simple kits to build organic cell devices will be developed for high school students. An industrial company, Lightwave Power, is the GOALI partner and they will develop manufacturing techniques.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

1.Overview

The GOALI project involved improving the  efficiency of organic and hybrid organic/inorganic solar cells, and measuring fundamental properties of the materials. The  industrial partner was Lightwave Power Inc., a Massachusetts industry which made some of the photonic substrates we used for the research.

2. Intellectual Merit:

The following significant advances in organic and hybrid solar cell technology resulted from this project:

2.1. The electronic properties of an important organic solar cell material, PTB7,were measured in detail. Among the properties measured were deep defects, interfacial bandgap, and tail state densities  near both the HOMO and LUMO levels of PTB7. These properties are important for estimating the potential solar conversion efficiency of this material.

2.2 The electronic properties  such as deep defects, dielectric constant and tail state densities of the new PV material (Pb-halide perovskites), were measured for the  first time.

2.3 High efficiency solar cells were made in  both PTB7 and perovskite materials.

2.4 A new type of microlens was designed and fabricated to improve light coupling into organic solar cells.

2.5 A  new dual photonic structure was designed and fabricated to improve the light coupling into organic solar cells.

2.6 A new type of plasmonic-photonic structure was employed to significantly increase the light coupling into  thin film crystalline solar cells.

2.7 A novel organic solar cell with an inorganic heterojunction layer was fabricated which had significantly  better stability against light-induced degradation than a standard organic solar cell.

 

3. Broader Impact:

3.1 Dissemination  of information: Significant dissemination of our results was done. 23 invited talks were presented worldwide by Drs. Dalal(PI)  and  Biswas(co-PI), all acknowledging NSF support. In addition, 10 contributed talks were presented by the PI and co-PI. 12 papers have already been published. The PI was one of the organizers of a workshop at IIT-Bombay  in India on perovskite solar cells in May 2016, and taught a 3 hour tutorial  there on perovskite solar cells, and  also gave an invited talk on stability of perovskite solar cells. About 65 students and 20 scientists from all over India attended the workshop.

3.2 Research Education and training: 6 graduate students received their research training under this award.3 students have graduated with Ph.D. and 1 with a M.S. One of the M.S. students being trained was a female student and she will graduate during F2016 semester. In addition, two post-doctoral scientists participated in the research and were mentored to become independent scientists. 2 undergraduate students received research training under this program.

3.3 Impact on technology: The findings of the project have improved the efficiencies of thin film solar cells. In particular, the research findings about the plasmonic and photonic structures to improve light coupling in thin-film solar cells have been well received by the field, as evidenced by the  citation count to the relevant papers. The fundamental work on measuring electronic material properties of Pb-halide perovskites has also been well received with over 40 citations.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2016
Modified by: Vikram L Dalal
